subject: Re: Questions about testing using JUnit

Hi All,

  Thank you Scot for your reply.

  Let me explain my point of view about my questions in more detail.

  Abstract class is having partial implementation. Complete 
implementation of it will be provided by the non-abstract child 
classes.

  Also complete implementation of an interface will be provided by a 
class implementing the interface.  

  Implementation can be treated as contract which needs to be 
fulfilled by the classes.

  When we test a non-abstract class, we actually test all its public 
methods, which in a sense is its contract about its behavior with 
other classes.

  In case of non-abstract class, complete contract can be tested.

  How to decide contracts of an abstract class & of an interface ?

  After reframing my earlier questions, I want to know :

 1. How to verify complete contract which is based on partial 
contract provided by an Abstract class, using JUnit ?

 2. How to verify complete contract which is based on partial 
contract provided by an Interface, using JUnit ?

 This is having other facet as follows : 

 I'll be able to test all the non-abstract classes extending an 
abstract class & all classes implementing an interface.

 But many non-abstract classes will be written based on an abstract 
class, later on. Also many new classes may provide implementation of 
an interface.

 So how to take into account this future development while testing 
using JUnit ?

Regards,
--- Shivprasad M. Bhide

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Scott Stirling" <scottstirling@r...> 
wrote:
> > From: mangeshminal [mailto:mangeshminal@y...]
> >
> > Hi All,
> >
> >   I've following questions :
> >
> >  1. How do I test an Abstract class using JUnit ?
> 
> Extend the class and implement all its methods.  Then test the 
subclass.
> 
> >  2. How do I test an Interface using JUnit ?
> 
> You don't.  There's nothing to test in an interface.  Is this a 
homework
> assignment?
> 
> Scott Stirling
